Cytoplasm-The cytoplasm, or protoplasm, of bacterial cells is where the functions for cell growth, metabolism, and replication are carried out. It is a gel-like matrix composed of water, enzymes, nutrients, wastes, and gases and contains cell structures such as ribosomes, a chromosome, and plasmids. Unlike the eukaryotic (true) cells, bacteria do not have a membrane enclosed nucleus. The chromosome, a single, continuous strand of DNA, is localized, but not contained, in a region of the cell called the nucleoid. All the other cellular components are scattered throughout the cytoplasm.

The structure that surrounds the cytoplasm in a bacterial cell is the A. plasma membrane. B. ribsosome. C. nucleoid. D. cell wall. The structure that surrounds the cytoplasm in a bacterial cell is the: A. plasma membrane.

Cell Membrane. The answer is the cell membrane. The cell membrane is a phospholipid bilayer that completely surrounds a bacterial cell. The word 'completely' is important here because any break in the bilayer will lead to the death of the bacteria.

Shares & Saves. Save. bacteria image by chrisharvey from Fotolia.com. The cytoplasm of bacterial cells is enclosed by the cell, or plasma, membrane that separates and protects the internal environment of the cell from the external environment. It also regulates what enters and exits the cell.
